{{disambig-more: The eldest son of the [[Gerontius Took
Isengrim: Old Took]], Isengrim's rule was noticeably short. He was already near his nineties when he became [[Thain]], and died ten years later. As he had no children of his own, his brother [[Isumbras Took IV
Anglo-Saxon]] origin and comes from ''isen'' meaning "iron" and ''grim'' meaning "fierce".

{{disambig-more: It is likely Isengrim is named after an earlier [[Isengrim (disambiguation)
Isengrim: Isengrim]], but it is notable that "Isengrim" is the name of a wolf who appears in many medieval epics, including the story of [[Wikipedia:Reynard the Fox
[[Isengrim (disambiguation)]]}}: Reynard the Fox]] which originated in French folklore.<ref name="Nomen">{{HM
